content.content: Hello Maker community As you may all know what makerburn.com shows as income keeps dropping, and to my understanding the reason is that people prefer to get liquidated rather than paying their debt back. We should make Maker’s revenue recurring and reliable like what banks does when they lend money. I am sure I am not first one thinking about this. What are the obstacles to implement such thing? Can we think of other forms of recurring revenues as well? Thanks

content.content: Amin_Talebi:  and to my understanding the reason is that people prefer to get liquidated rather than paying their debt back.   I don’t think that is it. Economically this makes no sense unless you have a very small vault and the gas cost prices you out or something. The displayed income dropped for two reasons in my view.  CU expenses(+ Oracle costs? not sure) were added, and are subtracted from the total income of the protocol. Stability Fees have been dropped recently to try to counterbalance the growth of USDC backing.  Revenues of any business will fluctuate with user behavior, shifts in product-market-fit, and other exogenous factors. Finding sources of recurring revenue at scale is definitely the focus of many people here alongside building up a high-quality decentralized stablecoin that the that the world can benefit from. Another potential source of new recurring revenue could be from Oracles, but it is too early to say if it will make sense.

content.content: Maker went from a P/E of 8 to 115 in the course of about 2-3 months. The reduction in rates seems to be misguided. We did not see much increases in dai supply as a result of rate cuts, if we had, P/E would have been mostly unchanged in the end. The cuts had devastating effects on the sustainability of Maker because no revenue is being collected anymore. The reduction in profit has been so dramatic it is tempting to say it was a governance attack. There was no clear reason to change anything, as Maker was working well and seeing a lot of adoption, and yet we cut rates dramatically and saw no obvious benefits from doing so. It is one thing to seek to grow Maker like a start up, by earning nothing until someday capturing value. But this doesn’t work in a DAO because it creates too much incentive for people to extract value through salaries instead of through growth of value of the coin itself. Currently the expenses of Maker exceed the burn rate, and that should never be the case. Maker should always be getting burned and the P/E should be managed to be relatively low. We should increase the rates until the P/E stops declining.

content.content: Two things   The price of MKR did go up (along with the rest of the market) so dollar denominated P/E will also have gone up regardless of the changes. Perhaps not as much due to the drop in earnings but this isn’t the best metric.   The PSM’s growth rate did significantly drop. I will try to find the data but the daily increase in USDC in the PSM was crazy before the rate drop and is far more reasonable now. This was the stated goal of the rate cut: to prioritize removing our reliance on USDC at the expense of profits. That’s what is happening now.   Calling it a governance attack is a bit extreme as well. I think the community has vocal proponents both for and against the rate drop but that’s about it.

content.content: SCV:  Maker went from a P/E of 8 to 115 in the course of about 2-3 months. The reduction in rates seems to be misguided. We did not see much increases in dai supply as a result of rate cuts, if we had, P/E would have been mostly unchanged in the end. The cuts had devastating effects on the sustainability of Maker because no revenue is being collected anymore. The reduction in profit has been so dramatic it is tempting to say it was a governance attack. There was no clear reason to change anything, as Maker was working well and seeing a lot of adoption, and yet we cut rates dramatically and saw no obvious benefits from doing so.   A lower P/E would result in a lower MKR price, currently. I’m assuming you’re referring to the ‘E’ component of the P/E ratio and making the argument that lower stability fee ratios lead to a less sustainable protocol. I would take the opposite view. MKR has been losing market sure to other DeFi protocols who have even lower rates, especially when you consider liquidity mining incentives. So your statement that “Maker was working well and seeing a lot of adoption is factually not true” as the trajectory has been nothing but down since late April. It is not sustainable for MKR to continue losing ETH and WBTC market share.     SCV:  Currently the expenses of Maker exceed the burn rate, and that should never be the case.   Recurring revenues (SFs) exceed forecasted CU expenses by over $10M at current run rates. I would also note that our most serious competitor, in my mind, Circle, is forecasting negative EBITDA through the end of next year but taking stablecoin market share faster than anyone. I would also not conflate the success of a startup with P/E ratio. Look no further than probably the best capital allocator of all time Jeff Bezos who’s ran Amazon at a loss since start up and now is the most dominant force in E-Commerce and Cloud Computing.
